And now we remember a hit maker, the man who helped make Patsy Cline and many others into stars.
Hank Cochran didn't have an easy life.
He lost his parents when he was young and he was raised in an orphanage.
He ran away to work in the oil fields of New Mexico when he was 16.
Eventually, Cochran hitched his way to California.
He started writing songs, which took him to Nashville.
As one writer put it, his life was not as pretty as his songs.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""I FALL TO PIECES"")
(Singing) I fall to pieces, each time I see you again.
Cochran co-wrote that song for Patsy Cline when he first got to Nashville.
And he also wrote this one...
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""SHE'S GOT YOU"")
(Singing) The only thing different, the only thing new, I've got your picture.
She's got you.
At first, Cochran made $50 a week writing songs.
But it wasn't long before he was running the place that had hired him.
He wrote decades of hits for many singers, from Eddy Arnold...
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""MAKE THE WORLD GO AWAY"")
(Singing) Make the world go away and...
George Strait.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""OCEAN FRONT PROPERTY"")
(Singing) I've got some ocean front property in Arizona.
From my front porch you can see the sea.
I got some ocean front...
And Cochran was a performer in his own right.
Here's a song he wrote and sang in the '60s.
It's called ""Same Old Hurt.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""SAME OLD HURT"")
(Singing) Got acquainted with new faces.
I started going to new places.
But I got that same old hurt in my heart.
Hank Cochran was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer two years ago.
He died yesterday, near Nashville, at the age of 74.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""SAME OLD HURT"")
(Singing) Got everybody thinking I am a half smart.
I got a new vocabulary, even got a new canary.
But I got that same...
You're listening to MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I think there should be international intervention, international pressure on the regime and pushing towards a political solution, hopefully peaceful transition to democracy.
Yes, the Sidekick, a very popular mobile phone that's great for text messaging and Internet, it has had a massive server failure.
Now the company that makes the Sidekick…
Never a good sign…
Never…
…massive server failure, something you never want to hear.
You don't want to hear that on the weekend - no, no. Danger, the company that's make the Sidekick, is owned Microsoft.

They were having these server problems and over the weekend, they let customers know that some of the data that they have that's stored on the cloud, stored on the Internet - personal contacts, photos, things like that - may not be able to be recovered.
So, they were warning people don't take the battery out, don't let, you know, the battery die because all that stuff may go away and not come back.
And so, a lot of T-Mobile Sidekick customers were very upset, writing down by hand their…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…phone numbers so they don't lose them.
But, you know, this points to an issue of, you know, as we're putting more and more of our personal information online, you know, if there's not a good back up for it, you know, we could lose it.
But cloud computing was supposed to be this wonderful, great, new technology.
What does this Sidekick failure mean for that technology?
Well, when it's done right, you know, you have the data backed up in redundant locations.
You know, if something happens at one place, it exists somewhere else.
And it sounds like in this case, it was just a matter of just bad planning.
And it just wasn't backed-up properly and now customers are having to suffer for that.

We're about to go to China, where the government is trying to get millions of smokers to stop lighting up in public places.
First, we examined a public health problem here at the United States - the epidemic of childhood obesity.
It's a familiar problem, but still, the numbers are shocking.
In the last 40 years, obesity rates in school-age kids have more than quadrupled.
Treating obesity-related medical problems in children cost an estimated $14 billion per year.
Now, a philanthropic organization devoted to health care and policy says it's going to try to reverse the trend of childhood obesity.
The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, which also provides funding to NPR, announces this morning that it will dedicate half a billion dollars to the effort.
Dr. Risa Lavizzo-Mourey is the head of the foundation.
She says Americans and their children have become obese because they have lost sight of a simple concept.
We know that in order to have a healthy weight, the energy you take in, in the form of calories, has to be equal to the energy that you burn in physical activity.
